column4: Households Served by Municipal Trash Program
column5: Households Served by Municipal Recycling Program
column18: Weeks the drop-off center open to residents
column19: Municipal Buildings Trash and Recycling Service
column34: Does trash disposal tonnage include bulky waste?
column67: Did your municipality host comprehensive household hazardous waste collection events in 2012?
column71: Comments/Additional Information

We offer curbside recycling and solid waste collection to 380 central business district businesses, but we do not offer it to other businesses in the city. The CBD businesses do not have the room to have dumpsters, some have a hard time with the 64 gal. recycling carts. So the answer to #4 is misleading.
We offer 2x's week solid waste collection  and weekly recycling collection in the CBD.
The Cities of Amesbury and Newburyport just renewed their collection contract with G.Mello and IPR for another 5 years. We are currently working to secure a contract for a disposal site for July 1, 2013.
Enforced trash limits are 5 32gal. bags or 3 32 gal. containers.

Question 2B & 2C: All area college students (with valid ID) are able to use the Amherst Transfer Station WITHOUT the purchase of a sticker.  Because of seasonal (move-out) craziness we do not track the number of student households that take advantage of this benefit.  As there are over 24,000 students attending college in Amherst, this easily brings the number of households utilizing our transfer station to over 2000.

Question 9: EPS shipping peanuts were collected year-round at Transfer Station for reuse (made available free of charge to individuals, small businesses & UPS Store); We assume "household batteries" refers to alkaline batteries, which we do not collect.  We collect auto, all rechargeables and button batteries year-round.

Question 10: Pelham, Shutesbury, & Hadley are annually invited to collaborate in our HHW collection event.
Food waste collection for composting in schools was started in September 2012.  No comprehensive numbers yet.

Mixed paper is reimbursed on a market price per load basis.It varied from a high of $70/T to a low of $15/T.
Ashby is joining the Devens HHW Collection Center 7/1/2013.

We also service private commercial haulers that provide curbside recycling and trash pickup to local residents as well as non-Athol residents in neighboring communities.  The private haulers account for an additional 2023 tons of trash collected.  A portion of the recycling tonnage reported in question #8 is generated from the private haulers

Residents can use either tote size for trash or recycling typically a family household size of <2 than a 65 gallon tote for trash was provided larger households use the 96 gallon for trash.  This past year i am seeing a trend of households switching the size tote for trash vs recycling and we provide recycling stickers for that transition.  Eventually I would like to see the entire town using the 96 gallon totes for recycling only.

Our compost site accepts yard waste April - November

Our ewaste is billed by container not by tons each container can hold about 5000lbs and each container costs the town $650.00

We are the host community for Waste Management Single Stream Recycling Facility and they do not charge the Town to accept our recycling materials.
We recycle other items not included in any catergory's. Our Total Recycle for Calendar Year 2012 is 26,902, this does not include Demo that is recycled.

Certain HHWs like fluorescent bulbs and mercury have collection points open to the public during office hours.
Bulky rigid plastics numbers are included in commingled.
Bedford residents have access to 8 HHW days a year, but Bedford only hosts one ( at the Lexington landfill).
Yard waste tonnage only given for pick up, not resident drop off. ( we do not have a system for gauging drop off tonnage).

Each month a non profit organization in town (Girl Scouts, Boy Scouts, Food Pantry etc) signs up for cans and bottles in which they come in at the end of the day when the Recycling Center is open to pick up the cans and bottles so they can turn them in and use the money for their organization. Also, we do not have a method to determine yard waste. A lot of residents burn theirs during burning season and what is brought in is composted into a beneficial mulch.

In section 9:  Some items are available for every other week collection. As there is no way to check that off, they are listed as year round.

In section 9: Oil based paint collected one a year with HHW. LAtex paint collected weekly with regular trash as

Included in the commingled total are: 
glass
plastic (#1-7)
aluminum
furniture
metal
books / dvd's
car / truck tires
$159/ton is the cost for yard waste, CRTs, and freon items

We pay  $217.35 per haul to dispose of mixed recyclables. We do take smaller cardboard in our compacted recyclables, but separate out the large pieces to help with compaction.
We do collect white goods and e-waste for disposal, but it has been tracked by pieces.
We do not accept yard waste.
Wood, mattresses, and carpet tonnages are included in bulky waste tonnage.
Paint Collection and Paint Swap open 6 days per week from April 1 through October 31 each year at Recycle Center.
Latex paint is collected year round. Oil based paint is collected at HHW only
Cambridge residents can pay a fee to bring HHW to Lexington Minuteman Facility. Call Randi for further revenue info.

The Town of Charlton does not provide regular trash pick-up.  Residents and businesses contract with local companies.  Cassella located just over the Southbridge line, holds 4 Hazardous Waste Days free of charge for Charlton residents.
Paint is collected but only April until October (not totally year round).
1400 mattresses were shipped in 2012, tonnage unknown

Clarksburg has NO municipal MSW or recycling services.  Through NBSWMD they hold an annual Bulky Waste collection which includes electronics, tires, propane tank and scrap metal.  Their membership in NBSWMD gives their residents access to paint collection
Recycled tonnages included materials collected from two residental collection events scheduled in 2012.
Solid waste was picked up by the town from the high school for the 2012 year.  An additional 2 schools were picked up from August - December 2012.

In addition to our annual HHW collection day the Town offered for the first time a Styrofoam Collection Event, hosted at an elementary school the first Saturday after Christmas. The Town contracted with ReFoamIt and filled a 24 ft trailer 3/4 the way full

4. One pre-school participates in program, the high school does not. 
8. Cardboard includes some paper
8. Not all textile vendors pay revenue

The number of household served by municipal tash program 704 is te number of stickers soLd by the town to residnens.  the stickers are good for one year.  We accept residential trash only.  There is also an additional cost of renting dumpsters of$2,280.00

Item 8 was a bit confusing for me.  I took three different per ton figures (plastic, steel,aluminium) added them together and got an average for the per ton revenue.  Also we do not have any positive or negative for metal.   Hauler takes as a wash.

Styro  foam accepted in MSW - no recycling program at this point
Carpet and mattresses included in C&D
The City offers 3 sizes of recycling carts
White goods are collected at the recycling center but have not been picked up in calendar 2012.

Landfill Contract start date 1986. End date to be determined.
Cart Sizes vary. Single Family: 65gal Rec/65 Trash
Multi Family:95 gallon Trash/95gallon Recycle # of each varies by number of units in building.
We are ramping up our Recycling collection for Public Schools to be complete by end of year.
Business Recycling: We collect trash/recycling at 75% of the approx. 900 businesses.
Muni Buildings: We collect trash/recycling at approx 90%
Recycling Cost/Rev for Single Stream Curbsides Recycling varied from a high cost of -$20/Ton to a high rev of +$3.30/Ton

We also take Books, glass, eye glasses and rechargeable batteries.  Under section 9., we are unsure what numbers you would like for wood.  We do no not take wood at the recycling center, however we had 9,060 cy of leaves and brush collected.
Started collecting oil based paints at the Franklin Recycling Center last year to replace annual hhw event

Gardner's trash and recycling curbside program is wholly enterprised.  Businesses can opt in to both the curbside trash and recycling or recycling only. The recycling carts are available in 2 sizes 64 gallon and 96 gallon with 96 being the most common. Trash beyond the 48 gallon toter must be in the city's PAYT bags at $3.50 per bag- the hauler gets $1 per bag collected. Our transfer station is open for businesses to bring recyclables.
We do our own household hazardous waste collection year round at our Treatment Plant at 384 Deerfield Street
2c. Stickers not needed for recycling, only for MSW. All 4150 HH have access. But do not have count of Households Served by the Municipal Recycling Program
In 2012 the center has implemented two new services (bulky Styrofoam and used antifreeze).
E-Waste is not paid for on a per ton basis so no costs were entered.  Recycling revenue amounts were based on 12/2012 prices, but fluctuate.

1.)   "8. Recycled/Composted Tonnage" - Single Stream Revenue Breakdown = 60% (mixed paper) @ $22.50 per ton, 40% (Com.) @ $7.50 per ton.  

2.)  "OTHER RECYCLED MATERIALS" - Regarding e-waste, the city 's only makes money from TV's and Monitors - a fraction of the total tonnage and pays $450.00 to host the event.

3.)   Yard waste is typically calculated in cubic yards - in CY12 - 8,000 Cubic Yards - costing approx. $16,000 to take in and haul away. - Converted to tons is 2,160 + 312 tons (from annual curbside pickup)  = 2,472 total tons.

4.)   A city-wide curbside pickup for leaves is collected once a year in addition to the 35 week drop off location.  (312 tons collected in one day)

5.)   City collects refuse and recycling for approx. 300 Businesses.

The Town pays a $3.00 disposal fee per mattress.  We collected and disposed of a total of 29 mattresses this year.
We collect yard waste and brush.  The brush is chipped on site every other year.  The wood chips are available to residents with valid stickers at no cost.
Lanesborough has no municipal MSW collection.  All residents privately subscribe with area companies.
From May-Oct 2012 the DPW Yard Drop-off center was open to residents twice a month. Residents had the option to drop-off the following hazardous waste materials: used engine oil, propane tanks, etc.
283 tons of bulky waste was collected.

The Town of Ludlow started a PAYT program July 1, 2012.  These numbers are half a year with a PAYT program with the first 35 gallons free and single stream recycling.  The first half of the year there was no limit on trash and dual stream recycling

Hazardous Products Collection sponsored by CMW District.
Scrap Metal/White Goods, C&D Materials, Swap Shop or Book Re-use by CMW District.
#8 (other recycled materials) scrap metal/white goods and e-waste - CMW District.

Medical Waste/Sharps - Board of Health

Recycling Tonnage - cardboard, steel/tin cans, glass, plastic, newspaper - included in single stream.
MSW disposal contract with SEMASS began 1/1/1985 (outside allowed date range).

We are starting a composting distribution program in 2013.  We are considering a single stream curbside recycling program with 96 gallon toters given to each household.  We are also working with our Board of Health to impose mandatory recycling in conjunction with Waste Ban regulations.
Melrose does not track tonnage of items such as mattresses, carpet, wood and metal but it is collected. Food waste is not collected.
HHW collection partnered with Newburyport
Recycle quantities are unknown for yard waste, C&D, clothing, carpets, paint, etc.
Millis residents may dispose of household hazardous waste in the near by Town of Norfolk for a fee.

Needham accepts trash and recycling from residents, muni, school and also from private residential haulers and contractors. The tonnage figures include all of these. Because the private hauler and contractor trash tonnage is included in our figures, these numbers do not truly reflect the T/R rate for our municipally operated residential PAYT program.
New Ashford has no municipal MSW service.  Residents privately subscribe with area haulers.  They also have no yard waste drop off.  They promote home composting.

New Bedford recycled 853 mattresses.  From eight weight tickets, I found the average mattress to weigh 54.02 pounds.  I used this to calculate the mattress tonnage.

New Bedford recycled 28.03 tons of tires.  

New Bedford also recycles books and cooking oil.

New Bedford provides 64-gallon carts for recycling to buildings with four, five or six units.

CRTs and Electronic waste - the cost is $12/CRT.  Residents pay directly to vendor, City is responsible for abandoned units.  E-waste accepted at no additional charge.
Christmas Tree Collection occurs for 2 weeks  out of the total 39 weeks of YW (37 weeks leaf and YW and 2 weeks Xmas trees)
Latex Paint accepted M-F, May-October for reuse only
Residents are limited to one 64-gallon trash cart per week, additional trash carts can be purchased for a yearly fee (extra recycling carts no charge) and overflow bags are sold at local stores, however, we are not designated as a PAYT community
We also collect from small non-profits - their trash and recycling tonnages are included in the totals
We receive payments for scrap metal from Recycling Depot, but not for white goods collected curbside

*The Town of Norfolk Recycling/Transfer Station accepts Household Hazardous Waste one time per week (Wednesday) from April 1st through September 30th each year.  We are a member of the Charles River Household Hazardous Waste Consortium.

*Question #8:  The value in the section "Revenue/cost per ton"  for  "Steel/tin/aluminum/glass/plastic...." is an average of the various revenues/costs for all materials listed.

*Question #8, "Other Recycled Materials":  Tonnage for Scrap "Metal/White goods" is included in the "Steel/tin/aluminum..." line above (87.54 T metal).  Mattresses and Carpet are included in the Solid Waste tonnage, Question #5, and are not tracked indivually.
SSR at curbside, dual stream at drop off.

Latex paint is collected year round. Oil based paint is collected once per year.
We also recycled 8.28 tons of books
Glass costs $50.00/ton to recycle. Price for HDPE colored = $210.00/ton; HDPE natural = $410.00/ton; Finished PETE=$195.00/ton
E-waste weight is estimated as we pay a base price of $700/pickup

White goods collected-183 each ($25 to hauler directly)
CRT's collected-806 each (free to resident, Town pays fee)
Solid waste pickup $317,000/year for Town
Recycle pickup $207,000/year for Town

1) There is a private hauler licensed to collect trash and recycling in Northborough with about 750 customers, but their customers can also use Town Bags if they choose to.
2) The Town did hold two HHWD events in years past for free but reduced that number to one event per year when participation dropped by 80% due to the introduction of a $10 per box fee.
3) Single Stream recycling started on July 1, 2011 so all recycling data has been recorded as single stream.
4) The trash and recycling tonnage above does not include school amounts because the School Department hired a separate contractor to collect trash and recycling as of July 1, 2011.
According to WM Norwood condos and muni bldgs are collected using their commercial vehicles, so these tonnages reflect industry average based on current service schedule.

The Town of Oxford is a private hauler community.  
Two bulky waste dropoff days are scheduled in the spring and two bulky waste dropoff days are scheduled in the fall.  E-waste is collected during bulky item dropoff days.
The Town collects yard waste.
Residents are directed to privately owned and operated hazardous waste collection centers for disposal of hazardous waste.

Recyclables (paper,cardboard, newspaper collected together) and cans/glass/plastic are charged $180 per haul. No yard waste collected. Some of the question 9 materials,i.e. auto batteries and waste oil, are redirected to other sites in town for collection.
1,843 tons of C&D/Bulky waste were diverted including wood, carpet, and mattresses.

We have Avon, MA  join us for the Household Hazardous day every year.

Tires .43 tons
Propan Tanks 7.43 tons.

**Recycling Program - estimated 40% of households participate 

Question 4** trash pick up to business is only for small/family type businesses (offices) as courtesy (those not w/dumpsters)

Question 8 **Wood includes paint (paid to Clean Harbors Env. Services, Inc.)
                     TVs/computers are in pounds not tons (paid to ECER)

As of May 2013, the City did start collecting some Mercury items such as thermostats, thermometers and light bulbs. As of July 1, 2013 the City will also have a Mercury Shed, begin collecting sharps, and institute a comprehensive e-waste program which will replace the current sticker program and pilot program for e-waste.
Scrap metal tonnage is unknown collected at DPW
Savoy has no yard waste drop-off.
Rigid plastics are collected along with our commingled containers.
The cost per ton for yard waste is for grinding brush, but the total tonnage under yard waste includes leaves and grass.  Brush tonnage is 3001.
Under question 7: we have carts and bins for recycling, but are for DROP-OFF.  The survey wouldn't allow checking these off without "frequency of pickup" filled out as well.

Latex paint cans are collected at the curb when paint is dry.
Under Section 8, Other Recycled Materials, these are co-mingled. They are collected and diverted by Casella, Town's hauler. The Town does not receive a breakdown of all items (mattress, carpet
Citizens are provided addresses and contacts for other regional hazmat handling facilities upon request.  Information will also be posted on web site in the near future.

Medical Waste/ Sharps are collected by the Board of Health.  Mercury related products are collected by DPW and Board of Health.  A storage shed for mercury is located at the Town's recycling center and acts as a transfer location before final disposal is completed by Covanta Energy.
appox 245 msw + 100 dpw waste = 345 landfilled with no tipping fee and 238 removed off-site at tipping fee of approx $69 tipping fee per ton + $110 transport fee per travel.
put plastics 1 & 2 in Single Stream box with revenue info and plastics 3 through 7 and glass in Commingled box with cost per ton.
NEDT is in town and offers  walk in collection of HHW.

Yard waste - we also offer a permit for residents to drop off materials.  Tonnage numbers not included.
Rigid plastics - we are part of a DEP grant w/Salem and Marblehead for rigids but I do not have tonnage amounts
Electronic waste - we have 2 drop-off events.  Do not know the tonnage calculations.
Swansea holds a Household Hazardous Waste Day every other year. One is scheduled for April 13, 2013
City is in the process of placing two kiosks at the police station, one for waste medications and one for sharps.

The Recycling Department collects thermostats and thermometers.

Waltham residents can buy compost bins on State contract in the town of Lexington, by special agreement.

THe City provides five days of leaf vacuuming in November & December.

The City collects only dried cans of latex paint for trash.

The town of Wareham has a contract with a private Disposal Company for Muncipal buildings for both trash & recyclables.  It has nothing for residents except the following:
1. The town has partially funded a Drop-off Center located in East Wareham for recyclable items only.  In addition to the routine items the center handles: paint(both oil based and latex), tires, lead core and rechargeable batteries, flourescent lamps and bulbs, other mercury bearing items, i.e. thermostats, thermometers and smoke detectors, old flags, white metal goods and misc. metal of all types.  No sticker is required.

As of July 1, 2013, the Town is eliminating the funds for any recycling activity.  This action jeopardizes our ability to operate the center.  In addition, it effectively eliminates the Recycling Coordinator from the town budget which will leave Wareham with no focal point for recycling.  The position of the town Board of Selectmen is that volunteers should handle all the activities and that the center should be self-sustaining.  The Coordinator spends at least 20 hours per week on recycling duties.  These will be dropped or be absorbed by other town departments.  This is yet to be addressed by the Board of Selectmen or the Town Adminstrator.
2.  The town of Wareham participates in the "Carver, Marion, Wareham Regional Refuse Disposal District.  This provides residents with two transfer facilities for trash and some recyclables disposal.  These facilities are located in Rochester and Marion.  There will not be any recycling facility in Wareham.  A sticker is required and residents can purchase these at the Harbormasters office in Wareham.

In December of 2013 the Town of Wellfleet will be going to Pay As You Throw.

Please note that on Part 5, "Solid Waste Collection and Disposal" , we started a contract on November 5, 1984, and have renewed. Your date only allows back to 1992.

SEMASS contract start date was around 1974 - the earliest date provided as option is 1994.
We collect electronics yet difficult to determine volume by tons.
Town disposes 208 tons of bulky waste

The company we contract with to run our transfer station (E.L. Harvey & Sons) does not weigh recyclables.  As part of our contract, they do collect them, but they are just combined with materials Harvey's  recycles through their own business.

Other totals not listed above are: 18,072 tons of books for re-use, 124 (count) freon appliances, 231 (count) propane tanks recycled, 1812 tires (count) recycled.
The dual-stream recycling tonnages  from the Springfield MRF do not include the multifamilies in the City which are all picked up by private haulers. Estimated recycling totals for these multifamilies are: mixed paper = 65 tons, co-mingled = 29 ton and single-stream = 500 tons.

RE: Steel/tin/aluminum/glass/plastic containers (commingled containers or sum of separate container streams) 

This section was reported as revenue however, glass cost $25 per ton and Westport collected 99.84 tons of glass.  The amount of revenue and tonnage listed in this section was for the steel/tin/aluminum/plastic only.

our e-waste is dropped off at the DPW yard at a cost of $5 per unit for crt's  and that is the amount it cost the town to have them picked up, other electrical units are free drop off as these do not cost the town. some hard to recycle items that the DPW

We collect latex paint year round at the Winchester Transfer Station. This year we composted leaves onsite to make into screened compost for municipal/residential use. 322 tons of the MSW  was C&D sent to Wheelbrator-North Andover.
We receive all the MSW
Windsor does not have drop off for yard waste.
we had 140 white good units and 370 crt units recycled in 2012. 1 bulk item allowed each week for "free"
Tonnages were not filled in for other recycled materials.
